name: Behavioral Parent Training (BPT)
summary: An evidence-based therapy that trains parents in behavioral strategies to manage child behavior problems, particularly disruptive behaviors and ADHD.
description: Behavioral Parent Training (BPT), also called Parent Management Training (PMT), is a structured intervention that teaches parents strategies to reinforce desirable child behavior, reduce disruptive behaviors, and improve parent–child relationships. Rooted in behavioral principles, it uses modeling, role-play, and homework practice. BPT has extensive evidence for reducing oppositional, aggressive, and noncompliant behaviors in children, and is considered a first-line treatment for ADHD and disruptive behavior disorders.

off_label_uses: Supporting behavior management in children with chronic illness
Parent stress reduction and improved parental mental health
contraindications: Parents unable to participate due to severe mental illness or substance use disorder
Situations with ongoing abuse or unsafe home environment
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe. No direct risks. Can cause temporary frustration as new strategies are implemented.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong for ADHD and disruptive behavior disorders.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple RCTs and meta-analyses support BPT as first-line treatment for ADHD, ODD, and disruptive behaviors.

sections.text: BPT is based on operant conditioning and social learning principles. It modifies parental behavior to increase positive reinforcement of prosocial child behaviors and reduce reinforcement of disruptive behaviors. Parents learn consistent discipline, positive attention, effective commands, and structured routines. These changes in parent practices reduce coercive cycles, improve child self-regulation, and strengthen the parent–child relationship.

sections.preparation: Assessment of child behavior, parenting practices, and family dynamics. Parents oriented to the behavioral model.
procedure: Psychoeducation on child behavior and reinforcement principles.
Training in positive attention, praise, and rewards.
Instruction in consistent limit-setting and non-coercive discipline.
Modeling and role-play of strategies in session.
Homework assignments to practice skills in real-life settings.
Review of progress and troubleshooting barriers.
sections.frequency: Weekly sessions, often with both parents or caregivers present.
sections.total_treatment_time: 3–4 months, longer if combined with adjunct therapies.

sections.pre_session: Check-in on home practice, review successes and challenges.
sections.treatment_phase: Teach/practice new skill, role-play scenarios, assign homework.
sections.post_session: Confirm next steps, anticipate barriers, plan reinforcement strategies.
sections.home_practice: Implement skills with child, track behaviors, complete reward charts.

uncommon: Increased conflict if both parents are inconsistent with strategies
rare: Dropout if engagement is low or barriers are not addressed

absolute: Parents unable to participate due to severe illness
relative: Significant marital conflict that undermines consistent parenting
special_considerations: Coordinate with child therapy or medication management when needed.

ideal_candidates: Parents of children with ADHD or disruptive behavior disorders
Families motivated to learn and apply behavioral skills
Parents seeking structured guidance for managing behavior
screening_required: Parent stress and mental health screening

practitioner: Licensed therapists or psychologists trained in parent management training models (e.g., PMT, Triple P, Incredible Years)

studies: Kazdin AE. Parent Management Training: Evidence, outcomes, and applications.
Eyberg SM, et al. Meta-analyses show BPT effective for disruptive behavior disorders.
Chronis-Tuscano A, et al. BPT is a first-line ADHD treatment per multiple guidelines.
sections.limitations: Requires parent engagement; less effective if parental stress, depression, or conflict are untreated.

sections.insurance_coverage: Usually covered under family or child psychotherapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: High—improves child functioning and reduces long-term healthcare and educational costs.

concurrent_therapies: Child CBT for anxiety or depression

sections.adolescents: Modified BPT programs can target parents of teens, focusing on communication and limit-setting.
sections.autism: Adapted BPT addresses specific behavioral challenges and supports skill-building.
sections.high-stress families: Additional parent support or therapy may be required.

items: Consistency between caregivers is crucial for success.
Programs like Incredible Years, Triple P, and PMT are well-validated formats.
